titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Records of the Research Institute for the Study of Man's (RISM) Medical and Social Anthropological Research in Bolivia RISM.RG.8
titlestmt.author: Collection processed by Ulla S. Holmequist and Ani Rivera. Processed with new finding aid by Emilyn L. Brown and Hillina Seife, June 2006.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Guide to Bolivia Project.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2023-06-13T13:18:53

change.item: Record edited by Rachel Searcy to reflect incorporation of 2017 accretion and revisions to descriptive front matter written by Sara P. O'Neill.
Updated by Jennifer E. Neal to incorporate materials being sent to offsite storage in 2019 and for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description
Updated by Megan O'Shea to prepare materials for offsite storage
Updated by Lyric Evans-Hunter to reflect the digitization of audiovisual materials.

did.langmaterial: Materials are in English and Spanish.
did.unittitle: Records of the Research Institute for the Study of Man's (RISM) Medical and Social Anthropological Research in Bolivia

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Research Institute for the Study of Man

physdesc.extent: in 62 manuscript boxes, 7 half manuscript boxes, 7 card boxes, 83 box binders, 4 custom boxes, 39 record cartons, 156 shoe boxes, 1 flat box, and 1 flat file folder

did.abstract: The Research Institute for the Study of Man Bolivia Project was conducted between 1964 and 1967 at the request of the Peace Corps. The project was organized and led by Vera D. Rubin, founder and director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM), and Lambros Comitas, assistant director of RISM. Under their direction, multiple anthropological and epidemiological teams studied six ecologically distinct communities in Bolivia in order to identify major health problems and to assess the implications of rural social organization to facilitate the work of development agencies. The collection dates from 1935 to 2006, with the bulk of the material dating between 1964 and 1967. The collection documents the work of the project teams in Bolivia, and includes correspondence, accounting records, indexed field notes, laboratory processing records, surveys and questionnaires, maps, photographs, and films. The collection also includes materials from a 1997 exhibition, Retrospect and Prospect: Preservation and Use of Archival Materials in the Digital Age, about the Bolivia Project and the collection.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact university-archives@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open without restrictions, with the exception of materials in Subseries IV. F. Blood Samples: Blood Typing Cards. Repository permission is required for access to material in Subseries IV. F. Please contact New York University Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The materials associated with the Bolivia Project were created by teams of epidemiological and ethnographic researchers between 1964 and 1967 and transferred to the New York University Archives in 2006. In 2017 an accretion of correspondence was transferred to the archives by the Reed Foundation; the accession number associated with this gift is 2017.020.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p:
In 1964, an intensive three-year medical-anthropological research program in Bolivia was undertaken by the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) at the request of the United States Peace Corps and in cooperation with the Bolivian Ministry of Public Health. The program was conducted under contract with the United States Peace Corps and received significant supplementary support from RISM. The goal of the research was to provide basic information for the development of public health and sanitation programs. Project administration was carried out by RISM director Vera D. Rubin and associate director Lambros Comitas, along with William J. McEwen, who served as the project research director, and Abdel Omran, who was director of the epidemiological research.
The project had two interrelated research objectives: The epidemiological team attempted to define the major problems of health and disease in rural Bolivian communities, taking into account the drastically different ecological regions of the country. The communities surveyed included Villa Abecia, Coroico, Reyes, Sorata, Compi, and San Miguel. Clinical studies were conducted on a sample of 3,000 subjects to determine the incidence of tuberculosis and parasitic infections, the major endemic diseases affecting the region, and of nutritional and health status. Simultaneously, the ethnographic team conducted community studies in the same areas to provide background data on social and cultural features with special regard to attitudes toward health and disease and the structure of local institutions in the rural communities.
Over eighty medical and social scientists, field workers, nurses, data analysts, and staff in the United States and Bolivia contributed to the project. Quarterly reports describing the work and the course of research were filed with the Peace Corps. Results and analysis were published in two companion volumes: the epidemiological report, Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia, was published by RISM in 1967, and the ethnographic report, Changing Rural Bolivia, was published by RISM in 1969 and as Changing Rural Society in 1971 by Oxford University Press. In addition, a number of articles, reports, theses and doctoral dissertations resulted from the project research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date(s); Records of the Research Institute for the Study of Man's (RISM) Medical and Social Anthropological Research in Bolivia; RISM RG 8; box number; folder number; Research Institute for the Study of Man/New York University Archives; New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Decisions regarding the arrangement, description, or physical interventions taken on this collection prior to 2017 are unknown. In 2017 an accretion of correspondence was incorporated into Series I. Correspondence based on the collection's existing arrangement structure; at this point the descriptive front matter of the collection was also revised. In 2019, materials were rehoused by ACM and Preservation staff and sent to offsite storage. In 2020, materials were rehoused and sent to offsite storage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Records of the Research Institute for the Study of Man's Medical and Social Anthropological Research in Bolivia documents the work of anthropological and epidemiological teams in Bolivia and dates between 1935 and 2006, with the bulk of the material dating between 1964 and 1967. Material in the collection includes correspondence, accounting records, indexed field notes, laboratory processing records, surveys and questionnaires, maps, photographs, and films. The bulk of the collection consists of field notes taken by investigators in the course of their work, indexed cards created from these notes, and surveys and questionnaires conducted by the investigators. The field notes contain detailed observations of the day to day activities of the investigators, including their first impressions of the communities in which they lived, their interactions with residents of the communities, and maps and drawings of the communities. The indexed cards consist of photocopies of these notes that were organized by coded topics and cut and pasted onto cards according to these codes. The questionnaires include information about the health of the members of the communities, their living arrangements, and their opinions of social and political structures within the community. The surveys include information about sanitation, water supply, and livestock in the communities. Other material in the collection includes laboratory results of blood typing tests and blood and stool sampling for infectious diseases, maps of the six communities studied, census data for the six communities, photographs taken by the investigators, reports and papers written using the data generated through the project, and material created for a 1997 exhibit about the project and its records.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: As of summer 2019, materials in Subseries IV. G. and H. and Subseries E. and F. are missing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into 13 series, some of which have been further arranged into subseries. The series are as follows:
Series I. Correspondence
Series II. Accounting Records
Series III. Indexes
Series IV. Epidemiological Research Records
Series V. Ethnographic Research Records
Series VI. Surveys and Questionnaires
Series VII. Unpublished Manuscripts
Series VIII. Community and Regional Maps
Series IX. Photographs
Series X. Audiovisual Materials
Series XI. Exhibition Material
Series XII. Reports from RISM to the Peace Corps, Partial Reports Related to the RISM Bolivia Project
Series XIII. Miscellaneous Papers

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: In 2020 several boxes containing duplications of other materials contained in the collection were deaccessioned. These materials include parts of Series VII and VIII which were microform copies of materials from Series III as well as Appendix: Photocopies which included copies of materials from Series IV and V.

physdesc.extent: in 7 manuscript boxes and 3 half manuscript boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence relating to various phases of the project, arranged alphabetically by the correspondents' last names or subject matter. Also included in this series are final reports, telegrams, clippings, budget papers, notes, memorandum, film strips, articles, and curriculum vitae that are referenced in the correspondence.

did.physloc: These materials (Boxes 12-15) remain at the Reed Foundation. Please contact the Foundation for access to this series.

physdesc.extent: in 7 card boxes and 156 shoe boxes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has been arranged into two subseries according to type of index: Subseries A. Biographical Index Card and Subseries B. Community Study Outline Indexed Field Notes Card. Cards in the subseries are arranged by community name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of index cards that serve as a quick reference to the original field notes. The Community Study Outline Indexed Field Notes cards were created from photocopies of the field notes that were organized according to coded topics and then cut and pasted onto cards, arranged according to the coded topic. The Biographical Index Cards contain the names of individuals living in each community, their ages, occupations, and place of residence.

did.unittitle: Compi Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Coroico Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Reyes Biographical Index Cards A - Z
San Miguel Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Sorata Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Villa Abecia Biographical Index Cards A - M
Villa Abecia Biographical Index Cards N - Z
Subseries B. Community Study Outline Indexed Field Notes Cards

physdesc.extent: in 28 box binders, 17 manuscript boxes, 3 record cartons, and 2 half manuscript boxes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is arranged into eight subseries, as follows:
Subseries A. Blood Examination Laboratory Processing Records
Subseries B. Health Questionnaire / Cedula de Salud
Subseries C. Computer Generated Charts: Census and Distributions
Subseries D. Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia -- Final Report
Subseries E. Epidemiological Study Documents
Subseries F. Blood Samples: Blood Typing Cards
Subseries G. Investigation of Infant Feeding Habits (100)
Subseries H. Epidemiological Study Charts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series relate to the epidemiological study conducted between 1964 and 1967. Materials include health questionnaires (cedulas de salud), organized by community name, statistical charts based on the processed census information of the communities being studied, drafts and galleys of the final report and other documents published as a result of this study.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. Blood Examination Laboratory Processing Records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of blood examination laboratory processing records. The material in this series was organized in manuscript form by Dr. Franz Ressel, head of epidemiological laboratory procedures in Bolivia. The test results were indexed by Member of the Household Number.

did.unittitle: Subseries B. Health Questionnaire / Cedula de Salud

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 1,791 health questionnaires (cedulas de salud), organized by community name. The questionnaires were used as a preliminary census that documented the size of households and health conditions of family members. The questionnaires are in Spanish and include information about the family member providing the information, his/her age and health history, and information about the other members of the household. Some of the community files contain health questionnaires and tuberculin surveys. The latter consist of similar information as the healthy questionnaires and include information on tuberculosis titres taken at the time of the survey. The survey focuses on how many people live in the house, on the health of the members of the household, whether anyone in the house was very ill in a set of time not specified on the forms, and what sort of medical treatment that person received. The questionnaires contain the community household number, written above the page numbers, and the name of the head of household, which may also appear in the existing biographical index cards.

did.unittitle: Subseries C. Computer Generated Charts: Census and Distributions

physdesc.extent: in 8 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of statistical charts based on the processed census information of the communities being studied. Also included are computer printouts of what appear to be computer programming cards.

did.unittitle: Subseries D. Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia -- Final Report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials related to the final report published in 1967 as Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia in English and Spanish.

physdesc.extent: in 17 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains household administrative cards which include information about people living in each house visited by investigators, which medical tests were administered on them, and a household sanitation survey conducted by the investigators. Each folder contains lab result forms for each household member. The latter includes subjective questions influenced by first world bias, detailing water supply, household cleanliness, presence of insects, and presence of domesticated animals. Also included are tuberculin survey forms and lab result forms for blood and stool tests.

did.unittitle: Subseries F. Blood Samples: Blood Typing Cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries F consists of 2,192 blood typing cards placed in archival polypropylene binders. The cards in this series, housed to minimize movement and moisture retention, were used for blood typing and indexed by the Member of the Household Number.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Repository permission is required for access to material in Subseries IV. F. Please contact New York University Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

physdesc.extent: in 62 box binders and 4 manuscript boxes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has been arranged into six subseries, as follows:
Subseries A. Changing Rural Society Material
Subseries B. Community Study Outline (CSO)/ Bosquejo para el estudio de las Communidades
Subseries C. Field Notes / Notas de Campo
Subseries D. Codes
Subseries E. Community Census/ Censo de la Comunidad
Subseries F. Household Structure Diagram/Bosquejo de Casa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series relate to the ethnographic study undertaken between 1964 and 1967. The final report was published in 1969 as Changing Rural Bolivia. The report was republished in 1971 by Oxford University Press as Changing Rural Society. The materials have been divided into five subseries.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. Changing Rural Society Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a published version of the report from 1969, drafts and correspondence regarding the republishing, and correspondence and curricula vitae for people applying/selected to work on the Bolivia project as well as other projects in the 1970s and 1980s.

did.unittitle: Changing Rural Bolivia -- Drafts and Correspondence
Subseries B. Community Study Outline (CSO)/ Bosquejo para el estudio de las Communidades

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of the Community Study Outline (CSO)/Bosquejo para el estudio de las communidades. The CSO is an outline that was used to standardize and index the information recorded in the field notes generated by each anthropologist. The one exception is Compi, where the anthropologists were already present in the community conducting their own research. These forms document the information in the card files in Subseries C. Field Notes / Notas de Campo filed under specific numbers documenting geographic environment, population demographics, history and development, institutional systems, the sociopolitical system, community and private health, and the Peace Corps program.

did.unittitle: Subseries C. Field Notes / Notas de Campo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 14,000 pages and 30 bound volumes of field notes, organized by community and fieldworker. The field notes were processed by a team of data coders and analysts, who produced the CSO Indexed Field Notes Cards and the Biographical Index. The field notes are organized by community and then by name of fieldworker.

The field notes document the experiences of the fieldworkers, including descriptions of the villages in which they worked, people they met and spoke with through the course of their work, and drawings of buildings and other parts of the villages. The notes are in English and Spanish. Descriptions of medicinal plants in villages and what each can be used for; descriptions of relationships between villagers; work done by villagers; what women buy from markets, how much, and how often; health of the field workers; cattle driving routes; religious orders in the villages and religious events; fiestas in each village and the significances and different aspects (social and religious) of each. Two boxes contain court judgments in Compi and Villa Abecia.

physdesc.extent: in 3 manuscript boxes, 2 half manuscript boxes, and 35 record cartons

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this series have been divided into two subseries, Subseries A. Attitudinal Questionnaire /Cedula de Creencias and Subseries B. Household Social Survey / Encuesta sobre la Comunidad.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains questionnaires and surveys conducted as part of the ethnographic research study.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. Attitudinal Questionnaire / Cedula de Creencias

physdesc.extent: in 2 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, and 1 half manuscript box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries. contains 229 Attitudinal Questionnaires/Cedulas de Creencias. These questionnaires are organized by community and include the names of persons who were interviewed, mainly teenagers to middle aged men. These names may also appear in the Biographical Index in Subseries III. A. The questionnaires include questions on family, life, work, aspirations, and broad social and cultural attitudes. Specific topics include looking for work, repairing water sources, and raising children. Hypothetical situations are offered on each topic, followed by a series of questions based on these topics.

did.unittitle: Subseries B. Household Social Survey / Encuesta Sobre la Comunidad

physdesc.extent: in 33 record cartons, 2 manuscript boxes, and 1 half manuscript box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains 1,094 Household Social Surveys/Encuestas sobre la Communidad. These surveys have not been fully analyzed or indexed with other materials in the collection. Some materials were processed and analyzed by Jonathan L. Kelley and Herbert S. Klein for their study Revolution and the Rebirth of Inequality, published in 1981. The surveys consist of open ended questions about family life, household set up (including water and toilet facilities), family size, and opinions about community, education, work, and membership in labor unions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has been arranged in two subseries: Subseries A. Student Papers and Subseries B. Conference and Working Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series have been arranged alphabetically by author's name. This series has been organized into two subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The materials in this subseries consist of student papers prepared by students from Columbia University and the University of Kentucky. Students developed these papers during summer fieldwork studies conducted by Dr. Lambros Comitas, Assistant Director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Please be aware that FERPA guidelines may prevent access to student materials in the absence of a signed release form.

Series VIII. Community and Regional Maps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 15 maps, arranged chronologically. Most of the maps in this series were hand drawn and provide details of the communities being studied. The maps were also used for planting purposes and for building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographs and contact sheets depicting urban and rural landscapes, indigenous costumes, celebrations and festivals, musicians, market scenes, religious ceremonies, and interaction between the Bolivian population and members of the RISM epidemiology team. The photographs are arranged by content of the photographs, including men, women, work, politics, type of landscape, and festivals. Box 311 contains lists of photographs taken by Dwight B. Heath. Photographers include Kay Barnes and Victor Novick in Villa Abecia, William McEwen in Sorota, Herbert Klein in San Miguel, K. Barnes and Dwight B. Heath in Coroico, Victor Novick in Reyes, and Lambros Comitas and Vera D. Rubin in multiple locations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The photographs are arranged by content of the photographs, including men, women, work, politics, type of landscape, and festivals.

container.label: Mixed Materials [31142067123540]

container.altrender: Box Binder (2.5" wide, any dimensions between 12x16)
container.label: Mixed Materials [31142067123557]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Partly as a result of the RISM Bolivia Project (1964-1967), the United States Office of Education in 1968 and 1969 sponsored a study of rural education in Argentina, Bolivia, and Jamaica. The principal investigator of this study was Lambros Comitas, then Professor of Anthropology and Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and Associate Director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man.
The Bolivia CV Recordings, an integral part of this comparative study, were taped by Lambros Comitas in 1969 using a Sony Videocorder and CV reel-to-reel videotape for helican scan video recorders.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of 0.5 linear feet, arranged chronologically. This series contains articles, tables, charts and notes that relate to the Project's research goals. Some material is duplicated in Series I. Correspondence.
